episode.title: Tahoe-Sierra Preservation Council, Inc. v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: submitted We'll hear argument next in Number oh oh eleven sixty-seven, Tahoe-Sierra Preservation Council versus The Tahoe Regional Planning Agenc- Mr. Berger.
[Inaudible]

turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
There are three important things that should be kept in mind while we're addressing the issue this morning.
First, the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency totally prohibited a select group of individual landowners scattered around Lake Tahoe from making any use whatever of their land.
These prohibitions were never designed as the kind of planning time-out touted by TRPA and its amici.
Rather,

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: they were amendments...
Well, what about...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: a temporary order that says, gee, we're required by State law to develop a plan and it's going to take us a few months and, pending that, you can't develop? Now, i- does that invoke immediately some um per se taking rule?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: It does if it's a flat prohibition of use, Your Honor,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and if there is...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, I do believe that if it is a total prohibition on use, and there is no use being made of the property at the time, that it's part of the public project to have this freeze on use, and it's the public that ought to be paying for that project, not the individual landowners who are frozen out.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: S- s- Suppose that and then we have to play with the facts a little bit, i- it's a hypothetical case, but that within a month from now the World Trade Center is ready to be constructed and New York says and the owner wants to rebuild highrises for office only, and the city says, wait a minute, this is so important to the whole city, we need a year to think about it, a year in addition to the usual zoning process.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I think if they t- if they forbid the entire use of the property and don't allow any applications for use to be made, don't allow...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the owner to do anything...

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I- If there is some reasonable, economically viable, productive use that can be made of the property at the time, then I don't believe we have a per se taking.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I I guess my my my my question and I know you had a a more general introduction that we're interrupting, i- is is the use of a moratorium a st- a standard instrument of zoning policy, or is it very rare? I I couldn't find anything in the briefs on this.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: It has, I believe, become much more rare these days.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wh- i- wh- My impression is that that most of these mora- moratoriums, or moratoria, whatever they're called, would not would not be total.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: That's correct, Justice...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Scalia, and I...

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I think that's the more typical kind of moratorium, and the kind that most of the amici on the a- agency's side have been talking about.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There was one Minnesota moratorium that was seemed somewhat like this that had been sustained by, I think the Minnesota appellate court.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: There was one, Your Honor, and I would submit that that court erred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And we believe that...

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: And we believe that that that simply is not an appropriate precedent for this Court...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: to follow.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: why is it I guess this is going to be your basic point.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Because it's not the diminution in value that we're talking about here, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: that car for the year.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: the respondent here had simply said, we're g- we're going to need your property for three years, and so we're going to take a leasehold interest for three years, the respondent would have had to compensate for that.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Chief Justice, I couldn't agree with that more, and I believe that that is in fact what we're dealing with here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: well you're it seems to me you're not dealing with that here, because in that hypothetical the person, the the third party in fact takes the property in the sense of using it for that party's own benefit.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: That's true, Justice Souter, but frankly I don't see the difference between them, because...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the Government...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: the person taking in the one hypothetical gets a considerable personal value, I E, the use of a car, or the use of property for a period of time.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Absolutely true, but th- this Court's jurisprudence has always examined cases like this from the impact on the property owner, not from what the the Government gains by the taking.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Chamber of Commerce case a century ago.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: isn't your argument, and wasn't your answer to Justice Breyer's question in effect to invoke the kind of standard language which has come out of the Lucas case? In other words, it is preventing all use of the property, or all economically productive use of the property, and yet Lucas derived that phrase in a circumstance in which the denial of economic use was assumed to be permanent.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Justice Souter, I believe that that distinction gets recognized at the valuation phase, not at the liability phase.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: fee interest.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: really saying is, if the I think, that if in in Justice Breyer's hypothetical there is a diminution in the value for this period of ten percent, that you've got to compensate for the full ten percent, and it seems to me that our cases are pretty clear in saying, that's not how you measure the compensation obligation.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Actually, your cases in in in quite a number of different circumstances say that if you do take one important stick out of the bundle, you may have well have taken the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: property in its entirety.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: except in First English, Your Honor, where this Court expressly said, and it examined all the cases, that temporary takings are constitutionally no different than permanent...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: takings.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: that that gets to the argument that the other side makes throughout here, that the assumption of that statement was that we had a taking in the first place, whereas the issue in this case is whether we do have a taking in the first place.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Well, that's correct, and what we're talking about here is a deprivation of all use.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: for the Court to deal with here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: use if you fit it into Lucas.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You've got to do...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: that in order to get into First Eng-

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I I agree with that completely, but I think that that what we're dealing with, if if you examine the facts of the case, is that from the time that these ordinances were enacted in nineteen eighty-one until whatever end point you want to look at, there was a total deprivation of use.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Berger, you may well have been able to prevail under the Penn Central approach, I assume, viewed in its entirety over this period of time, but that was waived.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in that?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: present a Penn Central...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: case, that's correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: pure and simple per se taking, as applied to, as it comes to us, what is it, a three year period?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Well, th- there there was this three year period chopped out at the beginning of the...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And that's...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: what we're focused on...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: here as the case actually comes to us?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: That appears to be what the Court is interested in, as the Court reframed the question.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mhm.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you this question, Mr. Berger? Just looking at temporary takings, and just looking at the liability stage as opposed to the the valuation stage, is there a distinction in your view between a regulatory taking and a physical taking?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I don't believe so, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So then in if your view course, the physical taking, even for ten minutes, would be a taking and there's no doubt about that.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: If there is a total prohibition of use...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For ten...

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: there is liability.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Berger...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: can you can you reconcile the different approach that this Court has said goes for spatial segre- separation, like the air space in Penn Central, and time segregation? It seems to me that if the one if Penn Central is the regime for splitting off the air rights, it should also be the regime for splitting off a a discrete period of time.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Your Honor, the this Court and other courts have always dealt with the the time value of property, if I may, differently than they have in in these spatial terms.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: with all interests, and they and it was...

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: condemned, all of them would be entitled to compensation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But that's...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: physical takings cases.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: And this Court has said in First English that there is no difference constitutionally, Justice Stevens, between the physical takings and the regulatory...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose I...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What do you what do you do about the fact that there is a a regulatory taking of of sorts whenever you have a permit system, let's say the normal zoning regime in which you cannot construct any any building on on your on your acreage without first applying and getting and getting the approval of the of the zoning agency?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Justice...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: During that...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: period, there has been a total taking.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Clearly you you cannot do anything until you've gotten the property approved, but it seems to me that there is a fundamental difference between a landowner working through a system whose end product is, at least theoretically and and probably very likely, the issuance of a permit to go ahead and develop something that is economically productive on that land as opposed to...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: being stuck in a system where you're for-

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: interval of time it meets your test.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I don't believe so, Justice O'Connor,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: because...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: sounds like.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, what about...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: your basic zoning law? I'm going to, as a city, limit the use of this property to one house per acre.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, there you're permanently deprived of the use of it for commercial purposes.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but you are not totally deprived of the use of it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But can we get back to the basic question that Justice Scalia asked, and and Justice O'Connor asked it as well.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Because you are there in a process working toward the actual development of the process, of the property, pardon me, in contrast to being in a situation like these people are, where there is no process for development.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There is instead the desire...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: assume that the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency s- thought, in good faith, that there would be some development allowed, but they needed a year to think about it.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: B- the the difference is that in the second situation there is a conscious and total prohibition on use, and that's the purpose of the regulation, is to prohibit the use.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well then,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: it seems to me you have to...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: change your answer about the World Trade Center hypothetical, they say wh- there's going to be a very valuable use, we just don't know what it is, but we need a year to think about it, in addition to the normal zo- and you told me that that was a taking, but now your rationale seems to me to back away from that.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: If they are in a process where where there will be development at the end, then I believe that there is not an automatic per se taking, but it seems to me that what we're dealing with, if we've got a total use prohibition, we do have a taking.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's a question of time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: the temporary taking i- is whether the temporary interference is a taking or not depends on what's going to happen after the temporary period expires, because in one situation you think, well, they know they're going to get something valua- out of it, in the other they don't, but that that means that the test for the temporary period turns entirely on an evaluation of the future.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Well, if I made it sound that way, Justice Stevens, I I apologize.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the future...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: they're doing it just for the sole purpose of blocking the use.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Don't they...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: have some ultimate goal in sight here?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Sometimes they may.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But your your p- you rest on the hypothesis that they are just interested in a total blockage for a temporary period of time, they don't care what happens later.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: But that is the fact that we're dealing with.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We're dealing with...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: interest in protecting the lake?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: We have no question about their ability to protect the lake.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But it seems to me in effect and maybe this is a variant on Justice Stevens' question that you're saying, what's really wrong here is that this is not done in good faith, that this is not done, let's say, in in the in the case of the the period of time necessary to get permits, with with an actual development in mind.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Oh, I don't think it needs to.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And your argument in effect contrasts that with an existing permit system whereby if you comply with certain requirements you will ultimately end up with a permit, the purpose of which is to make sure you do comply with the requirements.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Exactly, Chief...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Justice.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, in in the one case the the regulating agency has said, you can't do anything with your land while we're thinking about the scheme we're going to adopt, and in the other case the agency has said, just as categorically, you can't do anything with your land while we consider your application.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Justice Scalia, in a sense that is certainly true, but in the case of the the processing of a permit application, we know that there is permitted use.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Not not d- not during the pendency.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: while the...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: application is pending.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: The the regulations of the agency say that for this property there is permitted use.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Under your theory it would seem that i- it suppose that a building i- catches fire and is substantially destroyed by fire, and the fire department comes, and the police department, and they block it off for a period of time, no use while this is investigated, none, property owner can do nothing, can't enter it, you're out of there.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I don't think at that point, Your Honor,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it fits squarely...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: within your argument.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: No, I think that in that case, Your Honor, you would at least be en- entitled to perhaps some nuisance examination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: circumstances...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: the question whether there's a taking turn on the the nature of the motive of the the b- b- b- underlying the regulation or the prohibition, and I thought your position was, regardless of the good faith and the great public interest in doing it, the the State has to pay when it does this.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Your Honor, I think we all have to live with what this Court called the nuisance exception when it decided the Lucas case, and that there are some things that the Government can do that prohibit all use that are not compensable.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Are you satisfied with the standard that says, every Government regulation is a candidate for a taking, just as every speech act is a First Amendment candidate, but it's actually a taking in this area only when the the impact of the Government regulation is not part of a reasonable process looking towards a reasonable form of regulated develop-?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: I think I could accept...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: that, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: they're going to say they win, because they're going to say, of course, this was an effort, reasonably, to regulate Lake Tahoe over a period of time.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Oh, I would I would disagree with that characterization.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Cer- certainly they...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: calculation, and that's the Penn Central aspect rather than the more categorical approach that you're urging upon us, I should think.

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Your Honor, if if they had come up with a a nuanced, subtle regulation that had something to it other than the meat ax approach that the agency took in this case, I think you would have a Penn Central type analysis, but what we've got in this case i- is not anything subtle at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is the...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: status today? What is it, twenty-two years later?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: We're twenty-two years...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: later.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor

turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger

turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it, is it your...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I just ask this...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: one question? With regard to those who have subsequently been permitted to develop their land, it's your view that you're nevertheless entitled to a t- takings compensation for the period in which the moratorium was in effect?

turn.speaker: michael_m_berger
turn.label: Mr. Michael M. Berger
turn.text: Yes Justice Stevens, that's true.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
